quizzes.title: History Quiz: Loch Ness Monster and Monster
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, leader, athlete. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In this movie Robert De Niro plays a timid and artistic NYC police detective. Bill Murray plays the criminal boss and Uma Thurman is a call girl De Niros character falls for.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mad Dog and Glory

questions.question: What is the Scottish Gaelic name of the Loch Ness Monster?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Niseag

questions.question: This was the leader of the group that searched Loch Ness in the early 1970s and claimed to have made underwater photographs of the monster.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dr. Robert Rines

questions.question: The exploration of the Loch Ness Monster is related to which field of study?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cryptozoology

questions.question: What is the profession of Mr R.K. Wilson, who was claimed to have taken probably the most famous picture of what was supposed to be the Loch Ness Monster?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Surgeon

questions.question: Which company did Clarence Saunders found in 1916?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Piggly Wiggly

questions.question: In which category did Krishna Bhanji win an Academy Award in 1982?

options.text: Best Director of a Foreign Film

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Best Actor

questions.question: This Saint is supposed to have seen the Loch Ness Monster and even to have tamed it.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: St Columba

questions.question: Who was the first professional athlete in baseball history to hit a home run and score a touchdown in the same week?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jim Thorpe

questions.question: Where is the loch, allegedly inhabited by the notorious Loch Ness Monster?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Northern Scotland

questions.question: Loch Ness is the largest body of water in which huge geologic fault?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Great Glen

questions.question: This town, closely linked to the legend of the Loch Ness monster, lies at the mouth of the river Ness.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Inverness

questions.question: What kind of creature was the extinct Plesiosaur, which is usually said to be similar to the monster of Loch Ness?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mesozoic reptile

questions.question: Which part  of the Loch Ness monster is most noteworthy according to people who claim to have seen it?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Neck

questions.question: In Major League Baseball, who was the first pitcher to win 200 games in his career?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A.G.Spaulding

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Thailand and Usa
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, fiction, sanskrit. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Rudolph Abel, considered the greatest Russian spy, was caught in the USA and arrested. What event led to his capture?

options.text: Another spy confessed and gave his name

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Somebody picked up a nickel

questions.question: Which U.S. writer of detective fiction worked for the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dashiell Hammett

questions.question: 1919 saw the first general, city-wide strike in the USA. It involved about 35,000 workers. In which city did this strike occur?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Seattle, Washington

questions.question: The poor man! He was diagnosed a bilateeral perobital hematoma. What does he have?

options.text: A tumor in the center of the brain

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Two black eye

questions.question: Which country had the largest prison population for 2006?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Peoples Republic of China

questions.question: In Hindu thought, how was Krishna killed?

options.text: By an arrow into his heel
By a knife into his heart

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: By an arrow into his heel

questions.question: Who was given a Honorary Academy Award  in 1967?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Enos Edward Yakima Canutt

questions.question: We all have learned that you can tell the age of a tree by the number of rings. Who was the first to discover this fact?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leonardo Da Vinci

questions.question: Where did Copenhagen meet Marengo?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Belgium

questions.question: Erle Stanley Gardner created the great fictional lawyer Perry Mason. On which TV show did the lawyer Perry Mason practice law?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Flintstones

questions.question: From which radio station was the first national US broadcast made?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: KDKA  in Pittsburgh

questions.question: What did boxer Jack Johnson, Charlie Chaplin and actor, Errol Flynn all have in common?

options.text: They were all charged with the same crime
They died of the same causes

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They were all charged with the same crime

questions.question: What was the name of Thailand before it was called Thailand?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Siam

questions.question: Who was the only congressman to vote against going to war against Japan on December 8, 1941?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rankin

questions.question: Which is the Sanskrit word for “union?”
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: yoga

quizzes.title: Science Quiz: Daughters and Example
quizzes.description: Test your science knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Science, john, example. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of the Bronte sisters wrote only one novel, which was published under the pseudonym Ellis Bell?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Emily

questions.question: Who was the first non-Muslim to make the journey from mecca to Medina?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Richard Burton

questions.question: What was the last name of the six brothers Carlo, Bindo, Alfieri, Mario, Ettore and Ernesto, who were all involved with automobiles?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maserati

questions.question: What business did the Wright brothers, Orville and Wilbur, operate before beginning their aeronautical work?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: cycle company

questions.question: Which one of Marie Curies two daughters, Irene and Eve, followed in her mothers footsteps and won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Irène

questions.question: For whom was US pilot, Francis Gary Powers traded?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rudolph Abel

questions.question: Name the actors who portrayed the Brothers Grimm, Wilhelm and Jacob, in the 2005 movie of the same name.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Matt Damon and Heath Ledger

questions.question: Which of Johann Strauss Is sons became known as The Waltz King and was instrumental in popularizing the waltz in Vienna during the 19th century?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johan Strauss II

questions.question: Which of these is a malapropism?

options.text: He is at the pineapple of his career.
Round and round the ragged rock the ragged rascal ran.
Water, water everywhere, nor any drop to drink.
Able was I ere I saw Elba.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He is at the pineapple of his career.

questions.question: Which is an example of a spoonerism?

options.text: Round and round the ragged rock the ragged rascal ran.
Able was I ere I saw Elba.
He is at  the pineapple of his career.
It is kisstomery to cuss the bride.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It is kisstomery to cuss the bride.

questions.question: This filmmaker, famous for directing Runaway Train and Tango  Cash, is the brother of Academy Award-winning director Nikita Mikhalkov.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Andrey Konchalovsky

questions.question: Which one of the Kennedy brothers became known as The Lion of the Senate?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Edward M. Kennedy

questions.question: What popular gun was invented by General John  T. Thompson?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: tommy gun

questions.question: After fashion designer Gianni Versace was murdered outside his Miami home, his sister Donatella stepped in as creative director of the fashion label. What is the name of Versaces older brother who became CEO of Gianni Versace S.p.A.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Santo

questions.question: What Academy Award-winning movie, directed by the Coen Brothers, features a pregnant small-town police chief?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fargo

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Eponym and Word
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, field, hangman. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: It is believed that this was the smallest dinosaur.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Compsognathus

questions.question: Which of the following is an eponym meaning a traitor to his country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A quisling

questions.question: Who was the first official Postmaster General of the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Samuel Osgood

questions.question: What was Beyonces first hit?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dangerously in Love

questions.question: In the Bible, he was the first person mentioned to be put into jail.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joseph

questions.question: Henry Wheeler Shaw is responsible for this eponym.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: josh

questions.question: What was the first nation to field a battle tank?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Britain

questions.question: What group included Nils Lofgren, Ray Bittan, Gary Tallent, and Soozie Tyrell?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The E Street Band

questions.question: We get this word from the name of an infamous hangman.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: derrick

questions.question: This very popular math term comes from the name of the man who wrote the first great algebra textbook.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: algorithm

questions.question: We get the word boycott  from the name of Charles C. Boycott, a terrible  landlord of the 19th Century. Where did he own land?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ireland

questions.question: We get this word from the name of a French Ambassador to Portugal.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: nicotine

questions.question: This simple but powerful bomb made out of a gas filled bottle was named after a Soviet politician and diplomat.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A Molotov cocktail

questions.question: We get this very popular word from one of Athenas aliases in Greek mythology.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: mentor

questions.question: An eponym that describes a mens style is derived from the name of this Union general.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: General Burnside

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: People and Country
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, pilgrims, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Admitted to the United States on January 3, 1959, the 49th state is both the westernmost and the northernmost US state.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: For over 1000 years most people believed that the sun circled the Earth. The  scientific basis for this  came from the book The Almagest written by this thinker.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ptolemy

questions.question: The team of this country won the first FIFA Womens World Cup.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The USA

questions.question: This town, situated in Hawaii County, is the southernmost town in the United States.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Naalehu

questions.question: Richard Gere is a direct descendant of the Pilgrims who came to the Western Hemisphere on the Mayflower.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This Motown musical quartet, founded in Detroit, Michigan, scored their first #1 hit, I Cant Help Myself (Sugar Pie, Honey Bunch) in 1965.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Four Tops

questions.question: Which of these is said to have occurred at Cenacle?

options.text: The assassination of  Arch Duke Francis Ferdinand

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Last Supper

questions.question: What was the first web browser that had both graphics and text?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mosaic

questions.question: The Victoria Falls are situated on the Zambezi River, on the border between which two countries?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Zambia and Zimbabwe

questions.question: This award is the oldest and most prominent film award, given annually for Hindi films in India.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Filmfare Award

questions.question: This musical comedy, directed by Nancy Walker, is a pseudo autobiography of 1970s disco group, Village People.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cant Stop the Music

questions.question: This short-lived American sitcom aired on CBS in 1995, starring Andrew Dice Clay and Cathy Moriarty.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bless This House

questions.question: Which of these was invented by William E. Spicer, a Professor of Engineering at Stanford University?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Night vision goggles

questions.question: What  does the Latin word facula refer to?

options.text: A region of unexplained loss of gravity beneath the earths outer crust
Bright spots or patches on the suns photosphere
A measurement of the suns reflectivity
A dark region on the suns chromosphere

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bright spots or patches on the suns photosphere

questions.question: What is the name of the chieftain, who in 1816, after the death of his father, seized power over the insignificant Zulu clan and transformed it into a nation?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Shaka

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Lovers and Song
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, john, frenchmans. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who was the first host of the popular late-night show Saturday Night (later called Saturday Night Live)?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Carlin

questions.question: During World War II, the Polish Second Corps fought bravely against the Axis forces. Which statement about the Second Corps is not true?

options.text: They escaped Europe by going into Iran.
They landed on Normandy Beach an hour after the first wave hit Omaha Beach.
There was a brown bear in the corps.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: There was a brown bear in the corps.

questions.question: What color is the sweat of the Hippopotamus?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Red

questions.question: You know these lovers were fated to meet because Of all the gin joints, in all of the towns, in all of the world, she walks into mine. Rick remembers all the little details - The Germans wore gray, you wore blue. These star crossed lovers even had their song. What song did Sam play when Ilisa asked, Play it, Sam.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: As Time Goes By

questions.question: This modern amphitheatre, officially opened in 1922, on the site of a natural amphitheatre formerly known as the Daisy Dell, is used primarily for music performances.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hollywood Bowl

questions.question: The car in which John Kennedy was riding when he was killed had a bubble top that was not used.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Look for me by moonlight
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Highwayman

questions.question: By what name did Marco Polo call the capital of China, present-day Beijing?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cambaluc

questions.question: What famous Frenchmans dying words were France. Armee. Josephine!?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Napoleon

questions.question: Why are portholes typically round?

options.text: Because a circle gives you the most area for the least perimeter.
To spread out pressure on the the ships covering
For easier and smoother entering from the outside
They are circular by ancient tradition.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: To spread out pressure on the the ships covering

questions.question: Matt Groening, the creator of The Simpsons, grew up on a street named what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Evergreen Terrace

questions.question: Who was the first pitcher in major league baseball history to strike out over 3000 batters but to have less than 1000 bases on balls?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ferguson Jenkins

questions.question: Why was Battery D, Harry Truman’s unit in World War I, so devoted to their Captain Harry?

options.text: None of the men died because of a battle.
Truman always kept his mens safety as primary goal.
Truman never asked them to do anything he wont do.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these.

questions.question: Television beamed their fairytale wedding to over 270 million viewers on July 29, 1981. Sadly, on August 28, 1996 a divorce was granted to the Peoples Princess  and her once Prince Charming. Who was the Princess referring to when she stated in an interview on the BBC, There were three of us in the marriage, so, it was a bit crowded.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Camilla Parker Bowles

questions.question: Let me in!  Im so cold, pleads the ghost of Catherine Earnshaw. In what 1847 novel will you find the story of the doomed lovers Catherine Earnshaw and the wild gypsy Heathcliff?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wuthering Heights
